STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
December 6, 2024
Jamie Prewozniak
HACIENDA DE LUZ
6350 W KL AVE,
KALAMAZOO, MI, 49009-9197
Re: License #: CI390407606
SI #: 2025SIC0000030
Dear Jamie Prewozniak:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Paul Fatato, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
427 East Alcott St.
Kalamazoo, MI 49001
(269) 251-2471
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000030
Special Investigation Intake Date: October 14, 2024
License #: CI390407606
Licensee Group Organization: Bethany Christian Services Inc
Licensee Designee: Timothy Andrew Nolan
Chief Administrator: Jamie Prewozniak
Agency Name: HACIENDA DE LUZ
Agency Address: 6350 W KL AVE
KALAMAZOO, MI 49009-9197
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 05/09/2026
Capacity: 14
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
10/15/2024 Face to Face Entrance Conference; Incident
Notification; Interview
10/16/2024 Face to Face Interview
10/16/2024 Email Documentation received

10/22/2024 Email Documentation received

10/25/2024 Email Documentation received
11/4/2024 Video Conference MDHHS Dispo-No findings
1

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There are times that staff did not intervene when minors fought
with each other, often resulting in children being injured. In one
incident a child hit another with a glass bottle. Staff did not
intervene and avoided the situation.
Investigation The original compliant included on an unknown date, a sexual
incident occurred between children. The situation could have been
avoided if the youth specialist in charge at the time was properly
supervising however, they fell asleep during their shift. There is
concern that staff members are falling asleep or on their phones
and not properly supervising the children. This was previously
investigated in 2024C0000846SI.
Prior Employee was interviewed via phone on 10/16/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported working at the
facility from July 2023 to September 2024. She reported
terminating her employment because she believed she was doing
a job that she never should have been doing. She believed she
was being asked to do more that she thought she should have
been doing at the facility and the facility didn’t offer more financial
incentives for the extra work.
Youth E was AWOL from the facility therefore no interview
was able to take place. Youth E whereabouts are unknown at the
time of this investigation.
Administrator 2, Administrator 3, Administrator 4, and
Supervisor 1 were interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
10/15/2024. They all reported not being aware of the allegations
prior to this meeting. They reported the incident with the glass
bottle was documented on an incident report and staff were
activity engaged. They reported a safety plan although not in
2

writing was established to ensure no more items that could be
used as a weapon were available for the youth.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
10/16/2024 2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She
reported working at the facility when Youth B struck Youth E with
a glass bottle. She reported Youth E came out of the shower
dragging towels and was upset that the towels were wet. When
coming close to Youth B, Youth B made a comment about Youth
E’s mother. Youth E went after Youth B, and they were
roughhousing with each other. Staff 1 reported yelling at Youth B
and Youth E to stop the roughhousing. As Staff 1 was walking
towards Youth B and Youth E to intervene, Youth B picked up the
glass bottle and swung the bottle twice at Youth E, before hitting
Youth E in the head on the second swing. Youth E hit Youth B a
couple of times before Staff 1 got between Youth B and Youth E.
Staff 1 reported backing Youth E back towards Youth E’s room.
She described this action as blocking Youth E and as she walked
toward Youth E, Youth E would step backwards until reaching
Youth E’s room. Once in Youth E’s room, Youth E grabbed a belt
and wrapped it around Youth E’s hand to use as a weapon. She
reported Youth A talked to Youth E, blocked the hallway so Youth
E could not pass and then held the door shut. Staff 1 denying
asking for help from any youth to back Youth E up into Youth E’s
room. Staff 1 reported speaking to the Therapist 2 who was
working at the time but has since left the facility. Therapist 2
informed Staff 1 to remove Youth B from the milieu and bring
Youth B to the other side (locked) away from Youth E. Staff 1
switched with Staff 2 so Staff 1 could escort Youth B to the other
side of the facility. She reported a belief that once Youth B was
out of the area, Staff 2 must have let go of the door. Staff 1
reported Staff 4 came to the facility and took Youth E to the
hospital and while Staff 1 brought Youth B back into the milieu.
She reported Youth B and Youth E have a history of not getting
along and there is a safety plan in place to keep Youth B and
Youth E apart. This involves separating Youth B and Youth E in
the milieu and having Youth B or Youth E sit in the front seat of
the van and the other in the backseat. Another aspect of the
safety plan is to ensure there are no glass bottles in the milieu.
Any items in a glass bottle are removed to a plastic bottle before
being available for the youth.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
10/16/2024 2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth A
reported remembering the fight between Youth B and Youth E in
the milieu and Youth B striking Youth E in the head with a glass
3

bottle. Youth A reported staff did not restraint either Youth E nor
Youth B but rather got between Youth B and Youth E and tried to
deescalate Youth B and Youth E. Youth A reported going into
Youth E’s room when Youth E was in the room and telling Youth E
to calm down. Youth A reported since the incident, glass bottles
are not allowed in the milieu or for youth to have access to glass
bottles. Youth A reported feeling safe because staff provide
supervision and protection.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
10/16/2024 2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth B
reported staff became involved quickly and because Youth B and
Youth E were intertwined, Staff 1 and Staff 2 pulled each youth
away from the other. Youth B reported Staff 1 and Staff 2 have no
blame in anything the youth did. When directed to leave the area,
Youth B was respectful towards staff and left. Youth B reported all
glass bottles have been removed from the milieu and if a youth
brings something back in a glass bottle, the substance must be
transferred to a plastic bottle and the glass bottle is taken to the
kitchen. Youth B reported feeling safe at the facility.
Administrator 1 was interviewed at the facility face to face on
10/16/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Currently, the
safety plan put into place after the incident involves no glass or
metal objects that could be used as weapons are allowed for the
youth. She reported the behavior management (CPI) was
provided to all staff following the incident between Youth B and
Youth E and all staff are trained for behavior management as part
of their beginning to work at the facility.
Youth C was interviewed via phone on 10/21/2024 2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth C reported being
present during the incident between Youth B and Youth E. Youth
C reported not knowing what occurred prior to the fight but
witnessed Youth B and Youth E hit each other and Youth B
striking Youth E with a glass bottle in the head. Youth C believed
staff may have gotten between Youth B and Youth E, However, he
was unsure, but Youth C was sure staff were telling Youth B and
Youth E to stop fighting. Youth C reported staff keep Youth B and
Youth E separated since the incident.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 10/24/2024 2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported being present
when the incident between Youth B and Youth E began and telling
Youth B and Youth E to stop. She reported trying to verbally
deescalate Youth B and Youth E before getting between Youth B
4

and Youth E. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 helped to separate Youth B
and Youth E and Staff 2 “worked” Youth E back to Youth E’s
bedroom. She reported Youth A was talking to Youth E to calm
Youth E down. Staff 2 witnessed Youth E with the belt wrapped
around Youth E’s hand and telling Youth E, not to do that. Staff 2
reported taking the glass bottle from Youth B before Youth B went
to the other side of the facility. She reported Youth E was taken to
the hospital by a 3rd shift staff (she was unable to identify the
name of this 3rd shift staff) that showed up.
Documents Reviewed:
Event Information (incident report) dated 3/27/2024 involving
Youth B and Youth E. This document outlines the incident having
occurred at approximately 9:52PM at the facility. This document
outlines the incident as described by Staff 1 and Staff 2. Additional
information is the emergency room visit by Youth E and medical
care was provided.
Emergency Department dated 3/27/24 for Youth E. The chief
complaint is identified as head injury. Youth E is documented as
denying any other pain aside from Youth E’s head where Youth E
was hit with the glass bottle. Youth E was found to have no brain
issues after the CT and no acute intracranial abnormality. Youth E
was discharged in stable condition and with prescriptions for
naproxen 375 mg (1 tab 2 times daily as needed) and
promethazine 25 mg (0.5-1 tab by mouth every 6 hours as
needed).
Safety plan for facility dated 10/16/24. This document outlines
the responsibilities of staff. Staff are to follow the licensing rules
and policies regarding behavior management. Staff will ensure
youth have no access to any object that could be used as a
weapon (glass or metal etc.). Staff are to continue using verbal
redirection and de-escalation when altercations occur with any
youth. This document is signed by Administrator 1.
Bethany Christian Services Behavior Management and
Discipline Policy and Procedures dated 7/16/2024. It is
documented that all staff are trained in trauma-informed care and
nationally recognized curricula in de-escalating complex
situations. Staff are trained in positive behavioral interventions,
defined as specialized interventions that guide, control, and
redirect children’s behaviors.
5

Event Information (incident report) dated 5/12/24 involving
Youth B and Youth F. The document indicates Youth F engaged
in behavior that threaten the safety of others through physical
aggression and verbal aggression. The fight began while Youth F
and Youth B were playing video games. Youth F began punching
Youth B before Youth B picked up a bottle and attempted to hit
Youth F. Youth F avoided the attempt and Youth B threw the
bottle against the wall. Staff 3 is documented as intervening
quickly, grabbing the bottle and calming Youth F and Youth B
down. Staff 3 worked with Youth F and Youth B until they were
able to have positive interactions with each other and presented in
very calm manners. The treatment team followed up with Youth F
and Youth B and a safety plan was developed with each youth
with a focus on having the two youth (Youth F and Youth B)
manage their impulsive behavior and conflict. The treatment team
also stated no glass bottle are allowed in the area youth live in
and alternative plastic bottles are to be used.
Event Information (incident report) dated 8/28/24 involving
Youth F, Youth B, and Youth H. The document indicates Youth
G engaged in behavioral that threaten the safety of others through
physical aggression. It is documented that Youth G took a laptop
computer away from Youth H by grabbing the laptop while Youth
H was using the laptop. Staff 5 talked with Youth G about
scheduling a time to use the laptop and how Youth G needs to
take Youth G’s turn. Later in the day, Youth B grabbed Youth G
around the shoulders and neck area and told Staff 5 to grab the
laptop from Youth G. Staff 5 remained calm and told Youth B to
release Youth G and Youth B did so. It is documented Youth G
just walked away. It is documented Staff 5 followed up with both
Youth G and youth about maintaining safe behaviors and work
through conflict with words not actions.
Event Information (incident report) dated 9/14/24 involving
Youth F and Youth E. The incident began when Youth F
requested the video game controls and Youth E gave the controls
to Youth F. Youth E believed Youth F had lied and became
aggressive with Youth F. Both Youth F and Youth E began
pushing and striking each other and Youth G pulled Youth E away
from Youth F. Staff 3 came running to the situation and separated
the two youth (Youth F and Youth E. Youth E and Youth G left
while Youth F remained in the area. Staff 3 and Therapist 2
debriefed with each of the three youth (Youth F, Youth E, and
Youth G. The treatment team will review the scheduling of video
game time and identify if any changes are needed.
6

Analysis The agency is found in compliance as based on interviews with
staff and written documentation staff intervened when Youth B
and Youth E fought. The facility provided documentation (incident
reports) of all the fights between youth during this past year
(2024). Documentation indicates staff were quick to respond and
debriefing involved helping the different youth develop improved
coping skills. During each of these incidents, the treatment team
also reviewed video recording of the incident to help with the
debriefings. The only concern appears the first use of a bottle by
a youth and the lack of follow through with ensuring bottle are
removed from the living area of the youth.
Technical Assistance:
Technical Assistance was offered to the facility in the aspect of the
facility updating their policy/procedure to include no bottles (glass)
in the living area of the youth and to ensure this becomes part of
the staff training.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training
Title
Rule Code & R 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
Section Rule 128. (1) The licensee shall provide an orientation program for
Description new employees. Job shadowing shall not be the only form of
orientation.
The orientation shall include the following:
(a) The institution’s purpose, policies, and procedures, including
discipline, crisis intervention techniques, and emergency and
safety procedures.
(3) The licensee shall document that each staff person whose
function is covered by these rules has participated in a minimum
of 50 clock hours of planned training within the first year of
employment and a minimum of 25 clock hours of training annually
thereafter related to the employee’s job function. At least 16 of the
50 hours provided in the first year shall be orientation provided
prior to the assumption of duties.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff are not properly trained to deal with escalated behaviors
from the children.
Investigation Administrator 2, Administrator 3, Administrator 4, and
Supervisor 1 were interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
7

10/15/2024. They reported staff receive annual training in all areas
and will provide documentation.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
10/16/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
receiving training and completing an orientation week when first
starting. She reported having over 100-hours of training.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 10/24/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Regarding training, Staff 2
reported receiving training on behavior management every 3-
months and understanding that staff are not allowed to restrain
youth.
Documents Reviewed:
Trainings records documented for 16-employees were reviewed
and the following trainings plus other were documented as being
completed; ORR Prevention of Sexual Abuse, Reporting and
Professional Boundaries, Safe Medication Administration,
Mandated Reporter, Safety and Security, Behavior Support and
Management Interventions, Code of Conduct, and Protecting
Youth and Staff. There is documented numerous other trainings.
All files had documentation of the orientation at time of hire, and
they met the annual requirement of 25-clock hours of training.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as evidence by interviews with
staff and written documentation staff were provided with trainings
to respond to escalated youth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Seclusion within secure and nonsecure facilities; seclusion plan;
Title prohibitions; reduction and elimination.
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4162
Section (11) All seclusion will be prohibited effective November 1, 2022.
Description
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff held a bedroom door shut, keeping a youth isolated in a
room preventing him from exiting.
8

Investigation Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
10/16/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 1
reported holding the bedroom door shut to keep Youth E from
getting out and continuing the fight with Youth B. She only held
the door for less than a minute. She reported understanding that
youth cannot be shut in their rooms but needed to keep Youth E
away from Youth B.
Youth E was AWOL from the facility therefore no interview
was able to take place. Youth E whereabouts are unknown at the
time of this investigation.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
10/16/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth A
reported once the weapon (belt) appeared in Youth E’s hand Staff
1 started holding the door shut. Youth E kept trying to open the
door, but Youth A kept telling Youth E to “not do this” especially
because Youth E had made a weapon of Youth E’s belt and
wanted to use it. Youth A reported helping to hold the door to keep
Youth E in Youth E’s room so Youth B could be taken to the other
side of the facility.
Youth C was interviewed via phone on 10/21/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth C reported not
observing staff holding the door to Youth E’s room shut.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 10/24/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 2 reported witnessing
Staff 1 hold the door shut on Youth E while telling Youth E to calm
down. She reported a belief that Staff 1 and Staff 2 followed
policies and rules except for holding the door shut on Youth E.
Documents Reviewed:
Bethany Christian Services Behavior Management and
Discipline Policy and Procedures dated 7/16/2024. This
document outlines prohibited interventions which include “locked
seclusion or isolation”, and confinement in an area such as a
closet or locked room is documented.
Analysis The agency is found in noncompliance as based on interviews
with staff and written documentation, Staff 1 kept Youth E isolated
in Youth E’s bedroom by holding the door shut so Youth E could
not exit the room.
Conclusion Violation Established
9

Rule Code Job description
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4111
Section (1) An institution shall provide a job description for each staff
Description position that identifies rules, required qualifications, and lines of
authority.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Therapist was placed in the role of therapist without meeting
requirements.
Investigation Administrator 2, Administrator 3, Administrator 4, and
Supervisor 1 were interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
10/15/2024. They reported Therapist 1 filled in for Therapist 2 for
a short period of time and will provide documentation on this
action taken by the facility. Therapist 2 was off on leave at the
time and Therapist 1 who is has a Master of Social Work was
asked to cover.
Therapist 1 was interviewed at the facility face to face on
10/16/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported
filling in for Therapist 2 who went on l leave. He reported Therapist
2 has since left employment at the facility. Therapist 1 reported
not having a Michigan License or Limited License for Social Work
when filling in for Therapist 2 but being supervised by
Administrator 2 who is fully licensed to supervise Therapist 1.
Prior to obtaining a new State of Michigan Social Worker license,
Therapist 1 reported he filled in for Therapist 2 only as a “coach”
and not as a therapist.
Administrator 1 was interviewed at the facility face to face on
10/16/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
telling Therapist 1 he was unable to take on the role of Therapist 2
until he obtained an active license with the State of Michigan
again. Therapist 1 let his state Social Worker license expire but
received the new license on 5/22/24 and began assuming the
duties of Therapist 2 when she went on sick leave on 8/6/24.
Therapist 1 was promoted to the role vacated by Therapist 2 on
8/30/24. Regarding any leave time for Therapist 2, Administrator 1
reported this occurred before she took on the role of Chief
Administrator at the facility and she had no knowledge of what had
occurred.
Documents Reviewed:
10

Email dated 8/10/24 addressing Therapist 1 serving as a
therapist at the facility. This email documents that Therapist 1 is
approved as a therapist per ORR records by Global Refuge.
Email dated 10/24/24 addressing Therapist 1 serving as a
therapist during Therapist 2’s absence. This email is from the
global refuge organization. It is documented that Therapist 1 is
indeed qualified and is ORR approved to perform clinical services.
It is documented that the facility acted appropriately regarding
Therapist’s hire and clinical practice.
Bethany UC Therapist dated 10/17/24. This is documented as
the job description for the therapist position at the facility. It is
outlined that the educational qualification involves a master’s
degree in social work or a master’s degree in psychology,
sociology, or other relevant behavioral science area. It is outlined
that there must be at least 2-years’ experience of post-master’s
program experience in child and family services, or counseling
preferred with an active LCSW or LCPC.
Professional Licensing and Regulatory Affairs. This website
documents that Therapist 1 received a “Masters Social Worker
Limited” professional license #6851117913 on 5/22/24 and it
expires on 5/22/25.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as evidence by interviews with
staff and written documentation Therapist 1 meets the
requirements of the job description and was approved by the
governing body (ORR) for the facility. Therapist 1 had an active
Michigan Social Work License starting on 5/23/24 and did not take
on the role of therapist until 8/6/24 and was promoted on 8/30/24
into the role. In the prior times Therapist 1 covered, he only served
as a “coach” rather than a therapist.
Technical Assistance:
Technical Assistance was offered to the facility in the aspect of the
facility updating their policy/procedure to be in compliance with the
State of Michigan requirements for a therapist even though,
DCWL does not regulate this issue.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
11

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation On an unknown date, a child injured their ankle playing soccer.
The youth specialist did not call the nurse hotline or supervisor or
ask for help.
Investigation Administrator 2, Administrator 3, Administrator 4, and
Supervisor 1 were interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
10/15/2024. Regarding the ankle injury, they reported medical
care was provided and they will provide copies of all
documentation regarding this incident.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
10/16/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth D
reported remembering injuring Youth D’s ankle while playing
soccer and going to the doctor about a week after the injury.
Youth D reported receiving medical care including pain killers and
bio freeze right away at the facility from staff. The doctor gave
Youth D a boot to wear, and Youth D was told to rest. Youth D
was to return to the doctor 2 weeks later, but Youth D reported the
staff responsible to take Youth D quit and Youth D missed the
follow up appointment. Youth D reported being asked by staff if
Youth D wanted the appointment to be rescheduled and Youth D
told staff “No”. Youth D reported the pain was gone and Youth D
had not been wearing the boot.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
10/16/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
remembering Youth D injuring Youth D’s ankle but was unable to
identify a specific date. She reported receiving a phone call that
Youth D had injured Youth D’s ankle and needed to be picked up
from the soccer field. Youth D returned to the facility and Staff 3
provided medical care to Youth D when Youth D returned. Staff 3
reported Staff 3 has a lot of experience in providing medical care
for a sprained ankle. She used the RICE method of rest, ice,
compress, and elevate to begin the treatment. Youth D was
provided medication to reduce the swelling and pain. She reported
this occurred the day before she left for a 2-day break and
informed Youth D and Staff 3 that if Youth D was still in as much
pain, a visit to the hospital should be investigated. She recalled
Youth D was up on his feet very quickly, saying Youth D was
12

feeling alright and she couldn’t recall, Youth D asking to go to the
doctor. Staff 3 remembered Youth D using crutches and a scooter
for a couple of days.
Documents Reviewed:
Incident Report dated 3/3/2024 for Youth D. This document
outlines that Youth D injured ankle and nose at soccer. Youth D
was brought back to the facility as told by Staff 3 and provided
medical care. It is documented medical care involved the RICE
method (Rest, Ice, Compress, and Elevate. It is documented
Youth D was given a boot to wear.
Bronson Sports Medicine Specialists office visit dated 3/5/24
for Youth D. Chief Complaint is documented as “ankle injury”. It is
documented that Youth D had a similar injury on his right ankle
about a month ago that was getting better but 2 days ago had
another incident with the right ankle. The ankle is painful and
difficult to bear weight. X-rays were documented as negative and
is diagnoses as a sprain of anterior talofibular ligament of right
ankle. Youth D was given a boot to wear because of a high ankle
sprain and a reassessment in 2 weeks.
Bethany Christian Services Unaccompanied Children
Program SWMI Medical Procedure without a date. It is
documented that any medical emergencies are promptly
addressed, and this includes the urgent medical attention to
prevent serious consequences such as death, organ damage, or
significant impairment of bodily functions. It is documented that
emergency incidents encompass critical situations that pose an
immediate and severe threat to a child’s safety and well-being,
demanding prompt action.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as based on interviews and
written documentation staff provided medical care to Youth D as
required and followed up with medical professionals.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
13

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
12/4/2024
______________________________________
Paul Fatato Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
December 6, 2024
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
14
